div.head: Brunel zeigt Fischer das Leck im Themsetunnel, 20. September 1827
div.p:
Today I went to the subterranean passage, or so-called "Thames-Tunnel", which was built beneath the Thames somewhat east of the church at Rotherhite and which has attracted the attention of the entire educated world both because of its bold and massive construction and because of an incident that occurred there. I was all the more anxious to visit it as I had seen the work when it was begun in 1825 and then again in its progression at the end of the year 1826. A boat took me there from London Bridge in less than half an hour, and, on arriving at the tower or shaft, I was delighted to hear that Mr. Brunel, whom I know personally, was present. After I had been announced to himKorrigiert von: «Nachdem ich mich bei ihm anmelden lassen» in Fischers Erstedition., he was gracious enough
not only to allow me to come down to the entrance of the tunnel where I was, but to permit me to cross the barriers about halfway down the corridor in the western part of the tunnel, which normally prevent visitors from going further, and to go to the very back, to the place where the accident had occurred. No one is allowed to go into the eastern part, where the railways are located, on which the carts or so-called dogs, pulled by the steam engine installed at the top of the shaft, run back and forth, supplying building materials, clearing away the rubble and discharging the groundwater, which still flows in from the cave-in of the Thames, in channels along the wall. With astonishment and pleasure, I now saw this tunnel, which had been extended across 565 feet, by now already beyond the middle of the Thames, and into its greatest depth, not only completely drained of all water, but every trace of the immense quantity of mud
that had filled it up before tapering out in a downward slope towards the tower or shaft, had been eliminated on the side walls (which shone once again in their original, grey, marble-like beauty). Not a stone, with the exception of the breach, which I will discuss later, was displaced neither in the tunnels nor in the tower, although the water, reaching the level of the Thames, was 70 feet high within it. The same can be said of the 36 iron shields (I would call them testudo of ancient warfare. Perhaps Mr. Brunel got the idea from them), which together weigh two thousand centner and are moved gradually forwards by bolts attached to the walls of the tunnels, which are always bricked closely behind the advancing shield. Three separate ones had been sunk a few inches sideways to resolve the breach. When I expressed my wonder at the short time, relative to the event, within which everything had been restored, Mr. Brunel said to me: "Yes, Mr. Fischer, it was no small matter, between thirty and forty thousand cubic feet of water and mud had to be removed; the latter amounted to about a third of the whole; then the hole in the bed of the Thames had to be plugged. The surface area of this, according to the survey made in the diving bell above it, was about 50 square feet, and the depth of it as far as the tunnel was 36 feet." Mr. Brunel attributes the collapse to a strong current on the floor of the Thames itself, which may have been caused by the ships anchored there for a time in two rows. The workers heard the rolling of the debris above their heads, and the water at first seeped only a little between the end of the wall and the iron frames. When I expressed my
wonder at the short time, relative to the event, within which everything had been restored, Mr. Brunel said to me: "Yes, Mr. Fischer, it was no small matter, between thirty and forty thousand cubic feet of water and mud had to be removed; the latter amounted to about a third of the whole; then the hole in the bed of the Thames had to be plugged. The surface area of this, according to the survey made in the diving bell above it, was about 50 square feet, and the depth of it as far as the tunnel was 36 feet." Mr. Brunel attributes the collapse to a strong current on the floor of the Thames itself, which may have been caused by the ships anchored there for a time in two rows. The workers heard the rolling of the debris above their heads, and the water at first seeped only a little between the end of the wall and the iron frames.
They recognized the warning sign and happily made their escape. Immediately thereafter, the water blasted away two layers of bricks across their entire width and filled the tunnel and tower like a forest stream. Indeed, it takes the genius and strength of mind of a man like Mr. Brunel, and the perseverance of the English, not to tremble in the face of such calamity, but rather, with all the force of the human spirit, all the advantages of their art, all the resources of money, despite apparent danger to their lives, to overcome it and to render it impotent, down to its last consequences. Already, beneath the twenty-two archways, whose pillars form the partition between the two tunnels for those coming and those going, the gas flame of the fixed installation erected by the factory itself burns from double-armed candelabra of cast iron, which are spaced every 18 feet apart from each other, while in the rearmost parts
of the tunnel, oil-gas, compressed in the usual portable vessels, is still being used. Mr. Brunel plugged the breach, as he told me, with sandbags and short, thin, leafy tree branches and oily clay (fire-clay). The little water that trickles in around the iron shields at the back, where I was, is removed merely by hand pumps, and coming Monday, the 24th of this monthDieses Monats., construction will begin again and the tunnel will be driven forward. Everyone is eagerly awaiting the success, as one can easily imagine. Before the catastrophe, there was not a single accident during this dangerous and complicated construction, neither during the sinking of the tower, which had previously been built on the ground and whose load was calculated at 1000 tons or 20,000 centner, nor up to the sinking of the shaft to its greatest depth, to which, until the provisional staircase structure
was installed, one could only descend on vertical ladders. Later, a man drowned in the tunnel where the boat carrying the directors to investigate the breach overturned, because, as Mr. Brunel explained to me, the mud was littered with scaffolding timbers that had been completely shattered by the force of the water. Another accident occurred with the compressed gas. A vessel filled with it fell from the top of the shaft and burst. By chance, this happened near a light, so that the escaping gas formed an enormous flame and severely burned a nearby worker.

div.head: Vater und Sohn besuchen das Arsenal von Woolwich, 26. September 1827
div.p:
After I had received permission from the Board of Ordnance in London the day before through the efforts of the Swiss chargé d'affaires, Mr. Prevost, I went with my eldest son to Woolwich to see the arsenal, the foundry,
the boring mill and the model halls, all of which I already knew, but to which I wished to give him access, thinking it might be of use to him in two ways, as a rifle manufacturer and as an artillery officer. After I had presented my permit to the commandant, General Fischer, I was again assigned an officer to accompany me, as in the past. As we descended from the office toward the foundry, we heard the firing of heavy artillery, whereupon I inquired of our escort if they were practicing or conducting manoeuvres. He said no, these were only experiments to determine the usefulness and practicability of an idea of General Foad, concerning the extent to which the section of a fortress, which might be particularly exposed to the fire of besieging artillery, could put up sustained resistance if protected by a revetment of a double layer of forged iron rods,
each 1½ inches in diameter, which were affixed to it and positioned closely together and crossed at right angles. The experiments were also to test the extent to which this iron cladding, 3 inches thick as a whole, would withstand the effects of heavy-calibre artillery. Since I was very interested in this demonstration, I asked him to take us there, a request with which he readily complied.

There were three iron twenty-four-pounders in batteries and bolted onto them, as they have it almost everywhere, were locks, the strikers or triggers of which were released by means of a rather long cord when the officer commanded fire.

The cartouche were of canvas and probably soaked in an alum solution to make them less flammable. The load consisted of ⅓ ball weight or eight pounds of powder.
The canister shot (very round) was loaded without fixing (which is anyway dispensable with the small margin of error that the English have with their accurate drilling and excellent ammunition) and without wad, as they were fired somewhat downhill. The wad, which we also saw, incidentally, was bunches of unravelled mooring rope.

Instead of the gnat or fly that we use for aiming on the front of our cannon, here, as on the metal cannon of all calibres, there was a notch in an oblong square surface slightly raised above the muzzle, which is much better for accurate aiming when the hit is what matters, since the shot cannot easily cause a parallax, or even cover the target. The distance the shot was to travel
was 630 Yards or 1890 feet to the rampart, which was specially built of earth, covered with hewn stones and then with the aforementioned iron rods. The cladding was not more than 8 feet in length and 6 feet in height and was hit very frequently.

Two of the cannon fired so accurately that their shots often hit the target right next to each other; one went mostly left and high. The shots, when they hit the iron, shattered into many pieces, although they were of excellent material, of which I took a fragment after obtaining permission. The front iron bars took the impact of the shot deeply and were mostly also shattered; the rear ones, however, remained unharmed, with the exception of a single one, which was also blown in two by the impact, but, nevertheless, retained its position unchanged.

I was unable to stay until the end of these experiments, for which "50 rounds", or 250
shots, were scheduled for today, as I had to return to London. On the following day, the plan was to bombard the object even closer by half; however, what I saw convinced me that, even if it should finally be completely demolished, an even stronger covering of this kind for a rampart located at the weakest point of a fortress would certainly provide great protective defence.

I made the usual rounds again with my son through the two model halls, and then in the casting and drilling workshops. In front of the rotunda lie a quantity of cannon captured from various countries, which are kept for their beauty or peculiarity in construction and, it pleased me to see, two immensely large mortars, cast in 1726, by Schalch of Schaffhausen, who, because he predicted that an accident would happen, which then
did when his warning went unheeded, was promoted from young journeyman foundryman to the position of royal foundryman in the arsenal at Woolwich, a position he held with distinction, acquiring considerable wealth, until a ripe old age. — I saw nothing particularly new in the rotunda since I reported on my visit there two years ago, which notes are now at the beginning of this addendum, other than a model of a device by Colonel Congreve to conduct the hydrogen gas that escapes during the charring of wood for coals for gunpowder underneath the retorts, in order to use it again as fuel by igniting it. This idea, incidentally, as far as I recall, had already been proposed and implemented much earlier by the meritorious Professor Lampadius in Freiberg in the Ore Mountains. What truly caught my interest were two forged swivel guns, or small iron cannon, shooting about
three quarters of a pound, which the English had taken from the Burmese, along with the state carriage of their sovereign.

These two small pieces are really remarkable. On the one hand, they prove to the connoisseur how far this nation, which is, incidentally, not uncivilized, still lags behind its conquerors in technical skills and, on the other hand, how much, based to the peculiarity of their construction, the striving of the human spirit for perfection and embellishment is to be remarked here as well, even if only in crude and artless contours. The need to be able to load heavy artillery from the rear was, as it seems, felt just as keenly in distant Asia as in war-hardened Europe. From all that I have already seen in this respect and as far as I am able to judge, I would consider this
Burmese idea, which they have certainly not borrowed and which I regard as new and belonging to them, at least at as good as any known to me, if not give it preference, since these cannon have the peculiar and certainly good thing, even if they are already loaded from the rear, of nevertheless possessing a whole and solid base piece.

The device consists of the following: the part of the gun called the vent field is significantly thicker than in ordinary artillery, and its calibre is proportionally much wider inside. The upper half of it, however, is cut away on the longitudinal axis, so that it forms only a semi-circular hollow channel into which the short reinforce is inserted, on which there is a hand lever shaped like a thin dolphin and which only contains the charge along with the shot. This reinforce is tapered, or conically pointed, from the front and around the outside,
but only very briefly, so that it fits into the bore of the cannon starting at the end of the hollow, which also has a corresponding conical widening where the reinforce is to fit, and at the rear it locks with its base to the part of the base of the large cannon, as much of it as is left standing. As irregular and crude as these cannon are finished, for one can certainly say that every stroke of the hammer on them is Indian, the craftsman, nevertheless, made an effort to work the nose of this gun into a flower similar to an open lotus.
I called these cannon "swivels" because there is a handle, or fork, around the two trunnions, which ends in a point at the bottom. To plant the piece, it is driven into the ground or a piece of wood.

In the model room of the arsenal, since I saw it and mentioned the most remarkable pieces it contained in the fragments from my diary of 1825, nothing special had been added, except a machine made by the custodian of the same on a large scale and already put into use, in order to strike a dozen of the ordinary rockets at once and, more importantly, quite uniformly. One must really be surprised that this simple idea has, as far as I know, not yet been implemented anywhere else. It consists only in a wooden frame in which twelve wooden hammers are set in motion by a shaft fitted with cams that project to a suitable length (in order to provide sufficient fall) and are turned by hand with a crank, and by means of the stamp on which they fall, they move the set in the shells that are fixed in the rockets also mounted on the frame.
I must also mention a very carefully considered and clever arrangement for the production of all kinds of fireworks and ammunition. Namely, that instead of building large pyrotechnical facilities, as is done elsewhere, where in the event of an accident the damage and destruction is great due to the number of workers and the combustibles and explosives, here, everything is done in individual, very small wooden houses, painted with oil paint and situated in a wide area at a considerable distance from each other, in each of which there is room for two workers at most. As a result, the destruction of a whole establishment within merely minutes, as has otherwise already happened, is impossible.

In the foundry, compared to other such workshops, there is nothing particularly remarkable, even their melting furnaces are not extraordinarily large,
which I consider quite good, however, as through this and through the great heat that can be obtained in such a reverberating furnace with a coal flame, the fusion of the alloy (tin and copper) and the resulting higher density of the metal, which contains (and which is certainly also very good), judging by the colour, somewhat more tin than the French composition, can be more fully achieved.

The boring machine, on the other hand (there are actually two of them, the long one for cannon and the short one for mortars and howitzers), deserves the attention of every connoisseur, who will leave the workshop astonished, where the gun is given the highest, especially intricate perfection with such simple tools.

While here in Albion, so rich in art and gold, iron and metal are, in fact, wasted on thousands of machines
and other objects, these boring machines, which, as everywhere, are also lathes, are made solely of solid oak, and only in those places where it is necessary are iron rails screwed on (on the two so-called cheeks, namely, to form the groove in which the boring bar runs), which, as is also customary elsewhere, is gradually advanced by the worker with the help of a gear.

First, a hand brace is used to make a small opening or recess in the centre of the gun for the point drill, and the same is used to drill about three inches into the hole. Then, with a specially made boring tool, the hole is made perfectly round and to the width so that the first spoon bit, which is semi-circular at the front and in its lower surface, can be inserted,
with which the gun is then bored to the very end.

When this first hole is finished, the successive flat rail-drills follow, at the front end of each of which there is a steel ring of the same width as the previous drill, which must serve as a "Guide" for the latter, so that the hole becomes perfectly straight and concentric. Finally, the reamer, or polishing drill, is used, which differs from the other in that it no longer has a guide ring but is rounded at the front, since the chambers of English cannon and mortars always form a hemisphere, which is certainly advantageous, as nothing of the cartridge can remain stuck and it is also easier to clean; it is also honed in such a way that only the side adjacent to the half rounding in front, against which the cannon moves as it rotates, cuts, while the opposite side has a rounded
polish-steel-like edge, which indeed suits this purpose to the highest degree.

To prevent every kind of "Shakes", which are copied on the metal in a most unpleasant, though often essentially not harmful way, this last drill not only shaves away an extremely thin layer, but on its upper and lower surface are screwed two half-round pieces of boxwood about 6 inches long, underlaid with playing cards, which completely fill the hole of the gun, are lubricated with oil, and thus also help to perfect the polish.

What struck me about this boring machine was that I did not see any so-called slides ("Sliding-tool; burin fixe") but noticed that the gun was turned from the rough with very simple lathe, which the worker only placed on a wooden trestle ("Support"),
and then finished with flat, right-angled polished rails. The contour of the gun was, incidentally, formed using a perfected iron template, which the worker placed on the back and front of the circle, which had already been preliminarily set to the appropriate diameter for this purpose.

This way, as the worker said to me, with whom I conversed for a long while, we can finish a piece of artillery faster than with the slide, which we also have, but which, as you can see, stands there unused. For the boring of mortars and howitzers, which are processed like guns for the initial opening, I saw a tool that I had never seen before, with which every calibre, whether large or small, can be brought to the appropriate width.

On the flat plate of the drill, whose diameter
is such that one can almost finish the smallest calibres with it and which, in addition to the half rounding at the front, also has a ring attached as a guide, there is a piece of steel rotating around a pin on the plate and bent down over the bar like a turning tool, on which an upright piston is riveted, which, because the hole of its pin is countersunk, can nevertheless turn, and through the transverse hole of which, projecting about one inch from the upper part of the plate, passes a round rod, equipped with a double attachment (so that it cannot rotate forwards or backwards, but rather in the hole of the piston), which exceeds the length of the boring bar somewhat and which is equipped at the back of the end of the boring bar with a screw thread, which passes through a lug with the same thread, which forms a part of the end of the boring bar. The outermost end of this
regulating rod, which is parallel to the boring bar, has a square pin to which a key is attached in order to turn it as desired and, depending on whether this is done with the left or right hand, the aforementioned bent turning tool of the axis of the boring bar is brought closer to or further away from it, fixed at the desired, or required, point and, thus, the width of the hole to be made is determined for each round of boring until the gun has its proper width. This has the immense advantage that instead of the large drills comprised of one single piece, only a small part must be fabricated, hardened and finished, and that, however it may be finished, the tool retains its usefulness to the full, since whatever length may be lost from the axis of the boring bar when the part is removed is restored with a slight turning of an adjustable lock; and thus the
diameter of this (universal I would like to call it) drill with variable dimensions can be brought precisely and consistently to the desired point each time. As for the drilling of the touch holes, the rounding of the trunnions and the formation of their surfaces and lugs, the former is done in the usual way and the latter as well, namely by means of a hollow cylinder into which the cutters are inserted.

div.head: Perkins demonstriert die Hochdruckdampfmaschine, 27. September 1827
div.p:
When I wrote in the diary of my second journey to England about the inventor of the steam gun, Mr. Perkins, based on what I believe I was able to gather from his physiognomy at our very first acquaintance (p. 54), that the realm of knowledge would be indebted to him for more than one discovery and that it seemed to me that the pursuit of great ideas occupied him more than the dusty
acquisition of earthly possessions, I might well believe that I was not mistaken about him. For in this short period of time, he has indeed again made such essential improvements to his type of steam engines (which are always distinguished above all others by the immensely high pressure he imparts to the steam and by the fact that, despite this, he has never had an accident), or rather he has invented new ones, so that one cannot but admire his genius in this physicotechnical subject. It is not only in view of the very small space which his machines occupy in relation to their efficiency, but also because of the perfect safety of the steam apparatus, although the pressure in it is brought up to 800 pounds per square inch, and of which one is inevitably convinced when observing it, notwithstanding his public announcement of it,
and the testimony of engineers given about it in pamphlets. It will hardly fail to happen that in the end, for his own efforts and the exertions of his genius, he will also be awarded a prize of honour, which, as it seems, they want to deny him in England, and not entirely without fervour, whereas, if he were in a monarchical state, where such acknowledgements emanate from the sovereign, he would already have received it.

I visited Mr. Perkins twice: the first time alone (he now lives in Grays-Inn Road), where in a few months he had erected a new building and a steam engine factory (he had ceded the previously owned ones in Regents Park to Mr. Gurney), which would have taken years to build on the continent, and the second time with my eldest son, since I thought it was worth the effort
that he should also see these beautiful, small and efficient machines.

Mr. Perkins gave me the details of these machines verbatim and also gave me the details regarding the advantages of the latest improvements, of which I omit the following statement from the last paragraph, which, if its correctness were proved by experiments and counter-experiments, would bring about an important amendment in the laws of physics and chemistry, but will in any case greatly attract the attention of natural scientists.

He said: "By experiments I have found that the heating material is ponderable matter and obeys the laws of gravity, and by virtue of this property I have managed to bring it down from the flues and back into the furnace, thus saving a considerable amount of fuel."

Since Mr. Perkins will not be exempted from proving this assertion, which, incidentally, he would be able to do at any moment, since the furnace and the machine are ready and in full swing, I will, without entering into any further discussion, only mention what he has told me about the price, size, weight and efficiency of the same, and I will only remark that even in these newest machines – which still have the peculiarity of having no eduction valves and whose pistons, which he showed me, are of a metal mixture that, as he claims, do not require lubrication, and in general are very useful because of their permanent connection to the cylinder, while he is also impressed by the speed of the machine, which, even when it must bear the applied load, functions with 100 strokes per minute, is incomparably constructed, being made of two rings,
one above the other, cut open at opposite points and therefore resiliently expanding and aconcentric in their thickness – I say that in this newest machine of the largest type thereof, he has made the improvement of giving it two cylinders, one larger and one smaller, where then the steam, when it has functioned in one, passes over into the other, and when it has also done its work there, is then fed to the condenser, a new device by which advantages are obtained in a high-pressure steam engine that were not had before.
England, which by all appearances does not quite suit him, will now likely lose him forever, as I heard from him that he was willing to go to France.

I received the following information from him about his latest steam engines with two
(unequally wide) cylinders, which he had set up at the place mentioned above and which I saw in operation.
Firstly. Such a 30-horsepower steam engine costs only two-thirds of the amount one has to pay in London for an equally powerful and well-manufactured one.
Secondly. It occupies an area of only 30 square feet, that is, 6 feet long by 5 feet wide, and its entire height, including the flywheel, which is 5 feet in diameter, is not more than 9 feet.

Thirdly. The piston makes 120 strokes per minute. The construction and arrangement of the steam pipes, which have to withstand a pressure of 5 atmospheres (= 750 pounds per square inch) when the machine is in operation, is such as to preclude any danger of bursting.
The machine, incidentally, is so simple that its size and weight is only a fourth of that of an ordinary atmospheric one.
Fourthly. Mr. Perkins is inclined to give not only the authority but also the necessary instructions to those steam engine manufacturers who would be willing to enter into an agreement with him.

Since Mr. Perkins was kind enough to share with me the metal mixture from which he made his pistons (which I saw myself, and which, despite their friction against the inner walls of the cylinder and their rapid movement, require no lubrication) and which consists of twenty parts copper and four and a half parts English tin, so it would be important to apply them also to journal bearings, friction rollers, grooves (coulisse) and other similar objects to see how useful they would be there,
for which purpose I also mention this composition here.

div.head: Peruvianischer Stahl und Besuch bei Sanderson und Huntsman, 5. Oktober 1827
div.p:
After a bad night's sleep, as is the case when travelling, and a breakfast in Nottingham, which again was much more like a lunch, in that in addition to tea and coffee and eggs and butter, there was poultry and three kinds of meat, I was glad to find myself in the coal district, which bestows life and wealth to this region, but especially to Sheffield and Leeds. Not only are the coals very good, but the two layers above each other, of which the lower is, as usual, the better and more powerful, are extracted with little effort, mostly by hand, and sometimes only with steam engines or horse-engines. Equally interesting to me were two other objects on the long stretches that I travelled through in all haste,
namely the castle of the former Lord Byron on the left side of the road on a hill in a charming area before Nottinghamshire, built in a rather ancient style and inhabited by him before he met his fame and his misfortune, called Newstead Abbey. Then, also to the left of the road, there was Hardwik Castle in Derbyshire, in which Elisabeth, acting as a woman and not as a queen, but abusing her authority as Queen, imprisoned her more beautiful rival, the unfortunate Mary of Scots, for a long time. This historically peculiar castle, which is also beautifully situated with a lovely view, now belongs to the Duke of Devonshire, on whose fair wife's eyes an honest sailor once tried to light his tobacco pipe, of which the short story goes as follows:

The Duchess once stood still in an open calesche near Tower-Steiers,
to await someone. A sailor, walking very close to her carriage, gazed up at her with unblinking eyes. At last, with her customary affability, she asked "my friend do you want something?" "Nothing Madam," he replied, "but to light my pipe at Your eyes". Smiling, she pulled out her purse and gave him a guinea, saying that this would not do and that he had better get a lighter elsewhere.
"Flatter me as you may," she often said to the distinguished gentlemen in her company, "yet none of you can pay me so fine a compliment as this person has done."

Approaching Sheffield, one sees only a single, massive cloud of smoke which would be equally as much trouble for Dr. N.Es ist nicht bekannt, wer hinter dieser Abkürzung steckt.
to blow away as would be the fog that constantly envelops London, for whose removal he patented a method.

Since I found that I would, in any case, arrive too late in Leeds to see anything important or be able to visit anyone, and Sheffield has many and varied attractions for me, I decided to stay there and to investigate, in particular, where or by whom the so-called Imperial or Kaiser, and then again Peruvian steel (two quite new phenomena in cast steel fabrication) are made, but first of all to visit and greet my old acquaintance, the cast steel manufacturer Sanderson. When I arrived at the factory, he was having dinner in town, and I was told that he would be back later. I thought that I might be able to find out where the above types of steel were made at the Tiltinghouse (steel drawing mill),
since they would have them drawn there, and so I went to the mill.

The hammersmith had an octagonal bar under the hammer, which had not been cast smoothly at all, having a great many transverse cracks, so he forged it again on the corners, but then put it down next to a similar one lying on the ground with the remark, "it won't do". — "No it won't do," repeated a gentleman standing next to him, "It's no good." "Can you not tell me, good friend," I now interjected, "where to obtain Imperial and Peruvian steel?" "No," said the gentleman who answered instead of the hammersmith, "of the imperial steel I know nothing at all, Peruvian is made by Messrs. Bixley and Green, but it cannot be worked, as you see, like this one I have made. My name is Huntsman, and I make the best cast steel here, and if you would only come to me at Attercliff,
where I have my manufactory, I would show you the like, which cuts glass. This one I have only made for trial with ores brought me by a gentleman from the East Indies. They make steel with it there, but it is no good, and there is nothing better for our steel than good Swedish iron". I watched them draw for a while, looked again attentively at their warming furnace, which I described earlier and whose suitability for their fuel I must again fully acknowledge, and then went to Messrs. Bixley and Green. When I tried to buy Peruvian steel in the store, I was not given any, but was directed to the office, where I was told to come back at eight o'clock, as they did not have any on hand at the moment.

103 I then hurried to Mr. SandersonKorrigiert von «Sanders» in Fischers Erstedition. in the cast steel factory on West Street, which was quite a distance away. He was in the office
and received me very kindly, as did his two associates, to whom he explained who I was and offered me lodging in his apartment if I should wish to stay in Sheffield, which I declined. After some conversation about steel manufacturing, I departed, and he accompanied me. Instead of going to the door, he first took me to the coal warehouse and showed me their beautiful (light) cokes and then, to my amazement, to the smelting works, which was in full swing. I watched the melting and casting for a while and then proceeded to the cement works, where they cement Swedish iron, known as Hoop L because of the sign (L), which is the best, and then turn it into cast steel. Their cement steel is really excellent and burned as uniformly as one could wish. I told him what I do with the overpour steel so as to make the best use of it,
which interested him very much, since they have also accumulated a large pile, and, finally, my thoughts about Huntsman's steel, supposedly produced from East Indian ores, which I judged by external characteristics to be badly imitated meteor steel, and added, I believe the gentlemen in Sheffield also plow with my oxen. "I see well," he replied smiling, "they can't throw any dust into your eyes."
Friendly, though competitors, we parted company.

In the evening at eight o'clock I returned to Messrs. Bixley and Green, but again I was unable to obtain any Peruvian steel. They said they would send it to me in London. I recognized, however, that they were simply unwilling to give me any. Mr. Bixley, meanwhile, invited me to join him upstairs and took me to his warehouses, six of which,
one more precious than the other, were filled with metal and iron goods of all kinds, which Birmingham and Sheffield supply, by which I also mean plated work, and each time I entered, as if by a stroke of magic, with the turn of a switch, the gas lights glowing on the crystalline lustres, like fireflies, were raised to blazing flames, spreading daylight over the shiny objects. Of the many beautiful and fine things, I only regretted not being able to buy one thing, as I was traveling through France, namely a beautifully lacquered tea tray of virtually the largest kind embellished with gold plating, which cost only 7 shillings or about 4 Guld. 12 Kr. Before departing, I courteously purchased a handsome and well-crafted pair of scissors, whereby he then gave me two copper engravings of his warehouse as seen from the inside and then, with great devotion,
took a flat box from a glass cabinet, which had a steel frame and a glass lid and was divided into seven gilded compartments on the inside. These compartments contained cupro-nickel, chrome-ironstone, silver, gold, platina, borax, and burnt alum (the latter both in pieces, which made them recognizable). "You see," he said, "we make the Peruvian steel you asked for, which is incomparable, with these materials. We do not sell it, however, but use it only for articles of our own manufacture." With equal devotion and admiration, I returned the sacred object to him and thanked him for the gracious explanation. I wanted to make the most of my time in Sheffield, where many an altar exists for the worshippers of Vulcan, and, though it was very late, returned first to the drawing mill and then to a rolling mill, since both are in operation day and night.
In the drawing mill, I examined the warming furnace once more and for a sixpence got the hammer stopped, so that I could talk to the hammersmith about it. This furnace, simple as it is, proves that the English know how to overcome so many difficulties arising from the nature of their burning material.

In the steel mill, the thing I wanted to see most was the disposition of the fluting and the successive application of them to the piece to be drawn, so that in the last cycle, where it is flattened, there are no burrs on the sides, as there used to be, and where the whole secret lies in the fact that the bar is so large that the narrow sides are not flattened at the edges, but remain somewhat half-round.

div.head: Kurzer Besuch der Familie Gott in Leeds, 7. Oktober 1827
div.p:
Diesen MorgenFischer muss sich an diesem Tag bereits in Leeds befunden haben. unterhielt ich mich mit dem jungen Herrn Gott über die Veränderung der Sitten und
Gewohnheiten, welche seit dreissig Jahren auch in dem Norden Englands, unerachtet der noch grössern Abgeschiedenheit von dem übrigen Europa, und der noch mindern Berührung mit dessen Continent, statt gefunden, und namentlich, wie sehr sich die ehemaligen so häufigen Boxing matches und Cocks-fightings (Faustkämpfe und Hahnengefechte) vermindert hätten. Er anerkannte dieses vollkommen, doch sagte er zu mir: erst kürzlich war ich Zeuge, wie weit diese Liebhaberei bei Einzelnen noch gehen kann (was die Faustkämpfe anbelangt, so sind sie nun ganz in die unterste Classe des Volkes verwiesen worden, wie Sie selbst auf Ihrer Reise werden zu bemerken Anlass gehabt haben, aber nicht so die Hahnenkämpfe), indem ein gewisser Lord Davy noch beständig 300, sage dreihundert, solcher Kampfhähne mit grossem Kostenaufwande unterhält, und wo sich eine Gelegenheit präsentirt, dieselbigen, und zwar mit Verwettung hoher Summen, gegen andere fechten lässt.

Es war mir als eine grosse Gunst vergönnt (weil sonst Niemand in die Caserne dieser Vogel-Miliz hineingelassen wird, in welcher Tag und Nacht zwölf Personen wachen, damit sie gut besorgt und nichts Gefährliches oder Vergiftetes ihnen möchte vorgeworfen werden), sie Morgens um 4 Uhr, ehe der Eigenthümer noch aufgestanden war, zu sehen, und anwesend zu sein, wie man ihnen ihr Futter reichte. «They were indeed highly fed,» fuhr er fort; sie bekamen in der That sehr reizendes Futter, und dieses trägt viel dazu bei, dass sie meistens den Sieg davon tragen.

Auch der alte (übrigens solide) Prunk bei manchen Gastmählern hat noch bei reichen Landeigenthümern, die man in ihrer Lebens- und Denkungsart zu den Country Squires vergangener Tage, wovon uns ein Tom Jones, Joseph Andrews und andere Bücher das Bild liefern, rechnen kann, statt. So comparirte bei einem solchen, welches ein gewisser Watson Taylor gab, ein Cup
Board (Schenktisch), aus einem silbernen und vergoldeten Blech von 30 Fuss Länge bestehend; und ich würde dieses kaum anzuführen wagen, wenn es nicht gleichzeitig mehrere öffentliche Blätter erwähnt hätten.

Wenn indessen auf dem Lande in der sogenannten Sittenverfeinerung nicht immer gleichzeitig mit der Metropolis Schritt gehalten wird, so ist doch der Verbesserungsgeist auch bei den gemeinsten Feldgeräthen nicht zu verkennen; und so wie einerseits die eben so schnelle als gleichmässige Vertheilung der Jauche (Gülle), in sofern sie aus einem auf einen Karren geladenen Fass, an welchem unten über quer ein geschlossenes viereckiges, mit vielen Hahnen versehenes hölzernes Rohr befestigt ist, während dem beständigen Auf- und Herunterfahren über das Feld oder die Wiese bezweckt wird, so ist das Anstreichen dieser und aller andern Feldgeräthe nebst Wagen und Karren mit Oel oder Theerfarbe, von der ich sogleich reden werde, eben so verständig, um sie
gegen Einwirkung der Witterung und das schnelle Faulen zu schützen, und auch Beweis dieses überall waltenden Verbesserungsgeistes.

Diese Theerfarbe besteht aus einer Mischung von Kohlentheer und Ocker, hat eine nicht unangenehme grüne Olivenfarbe, und verbindet mit äusserster Wohlfeilheit, weil diese beiden Artikel fast nichts kosten, grosse Dauerhaftigkeit und Wetterbeständigkeit. Ueberhaupt fragen die Engländer nicht nur immer, was kann bei diesem und jenem gewonnen, sondern sie fragen eben so oft, was kann erspart werden, welches einen eben so positiven Nutzen hat, weil der Erfolg immer sicher ist, der Gewinn aber nur erst durch den Absatz bedingt wird.

Alle sehr schweren oder festen Gegenstände, als wie Zäune, Gitterthore etc. sind mit dieser grünen Farbe bemalt; Gegenstände hingegen, die klein und leicht sind, so wie auch alle Pflüge, die einzeln im Felde
stehen bleiben, roth; welches sehr klug ist, weil man sie nicht nur auf grosse Fernen erkennen kann, sondern auch der letzte Span davon den Dieb verräth.

Als ich mich über die Menge und Wohlfeilheit der Steinkohlen von Warwickshire bis hinauf nach Yorkshire, unerachtet ihres ungeheuern Verbrauchs, verwunderte, so zeigte mir Herr Gott eine Karte der Kohlenlager, so weit sie in diesen Districten abgebohrt und dann ihr kubischer Inhalt berechnet worden, woraus sich, nur auf das gegründet, was man bis jetzt mit Zuverlässigkeit kennt, ein Vorrath ergibt, der bei einem fortgesetzten, dem jetzigen gleichförmigen Consum, auf tausend Jahre hinaus reicht.

div.head: Fischer besorgt sich Fachliteratur, 10. Oktober 1827
div.p:
In einem Buchladen im Pater Noster Row kaufte ich heute Urés chemical Dictionary, welches in seiner Art fürtrefflich und besonders reichlich mit Tabellen so wie auch vielen Zeichnungen ausgestattet ist, und dann mehrere Hefte von dem
wöchentlichen Register für Mechaniker, eigentlich Register of the arts and sciences. Noch existirt meines Wissens auf dem festen Lande kein weder in Wohlfeilheit noch Brauchbarheit diesem ähnliches Buch, obschon es theilweise in vielen technischen deutschen und französischen Schriften, und zwar mit Recht, benutzt wird.

Es wäre ein sehr verdienstliches Werk, und würde sich gewiss auch auslohnen, wenn irgend eine Buchhandlung Deutschlands eine getreue und verständliche Uebersetzung von seinem ersten Anfang an, bis auf jetzt, und auf die gleiche Art mit den lithographirten Zeichnungen ausgestattet, veranstalten würde. Da bei dem sonst so hohen Preise der Bücher in England ein solches Heft oder Nummer doch nur 3 Pence oder circa 9 Kreuzer kostet, so wäre selbiges wahrscheinlich in Deutschland, noch wohlfeiler herzustellen, und wenn es in einer oder mehreren Haupt- und Residenz-
Städten, wo viele Handwerker, Künstler und Studirende sind, herausgegeben würde, so würde mit Einemmale unter diese Stände eine viel grössere und mannigfaltigere Masse von Kenntnissen über das englische Maschinenwesen, und was eben so wichtig ist, über den Geist und Genius der englischen Mechaniker, ihrer Umsicht, ihres Raisonnements und ihrer Hülfsmittel, was überhaupt mehr gefühlt und aus eigener Anschauung erlangt, als ad oculos vordemonstrirt werden kann, verbreitet werden, als durch ein systematisches Lehrbuch, wo der Theorie zu viel Rechnung getragen wird, um allgemein verständlich und anziehend zu seyn, oder durch isolirte, mit fremdartigen Gegenständen vermischte Beschreibungen, so wie sie in periodischen Schriften Vorkommen, und der Nutzen würde sich in kurzer Zeit auffallend zeigen. Die Hefte die ich kaufte, enthielten nebst mehrerem Andern Perkins neueste Dampfmaschine mit zwei ungleichen Cylindern, der
Injectionsröhre, dem Condensator und der Steamchamber, und dann noch die zwei neuesten Dampfkutschen von Gurney in Regents Park und von Mosley in Southwark. Beide diese Kutschen erfuhren indessen bei der ersten Probe einen Unfall. Bei Mosley’s, der für die Probe eine besondere eingeschlossene Wiese gemiethet hatte, zersprang der Dampfkessel, und einige Personen wurden durch das ausspritzende siedende Wasser beschädigt, und bei Gurney’s brach ein Rad, nachdem er wieder den ziemlich steilen Hügel, Highgatehill genannt, herunterfuhr, während bei dem Hinauffahren, was eher zu befürchten war, sich gar nichts ereignet hatte; übrigens kam Niemand bei diesem Unfalle zu Schaden, und es müsste mich Alles täuschen, wenn die Dampfkutschen nicht noch eben so vollkommen und sicher als wie die Dampfboote zu Stande kommen würden.

div.head: Besichtigung der Hammersmith Bridge und Theaterbesuch, 11. Oktober 1827
div.p:
Da ich in den öffentlichen Blättern gelesen, dass die neue
Kettenbrücke bei Hamersmith nun ganz fertig und für Passage zu Wagen und zu Fuss geöffnet sey, so ging ich mit meinem ältesten Sohn hin, um sie zu sehen. Der erste Eindruck, den selbige auf mich machte, war nicht ganz der angenehmste, in sofern als mir die Massivität der Stangen oder Kettenglieder zu ihrer Länge zu dick und plump schien, besonders im Vergleich derjenigen, die durch Herrn Baron v. Mitis in Wien construirt worden; und zwar schien mir ihre Dicke noch darum zu gross, weil vier doppelte Reihen solcher Ketten, wovon die inwendige aus sechs nebeneinanderliegenden ¾ Zoll dicken und 5 Zoll hohen Schienen, und die auswendige Reihe, die den Weg für die Fussgänger trägt, aus drei solcher Schienen besteht, auf jeder Seite nebeneinander hinlaufen. Es ist freilich wahr, Herr v. Mitis hatte die fürtreffliche Idee, nachdem er die verschiedene Cohäsionskraft von Eisen und Stahl gegeneinander vorher durch seine ingeniöse Maschine
untersucht, und zu dem merkwürdigen, vorher noch nicht so gekannten Resultat gelangt war, dass die Stärke des ordinären Stahls sich zu dem von gutem Eisen wenigstens wie 9 zu 4 verhalte, und also die Möglichkeit gewähre, die Glieder mit grösster Sicherheit, wo nicht um die Hälfte, doch wenigstens um ein Drittheil dünner zu machen, und so in den gesammten Constructions-Kosten, da die Widerlager auch leichter seyn durften, ein Vortheil gegen eine Kettenbrücke von Eisen wie 16 zu 11 erhalten würde; das heisst, wenn eine Brücke von Eisen 16,000 Gulden kostet, so kommt eine von Stahl nur auf 11,000 Gulden zu stehen. Die Brücke in Hamersmith besteht übrigens aus zwei Bogen, wovon der eine eine Länge von 400 Fuss und 3 Zoll, und der andere von 140 Fuss hat, indem noch in der Themse selbst, was übrigens sehr verständig und vortheilhaft war, ein grosser Pfeiler von Stein aufgeführt ist, auf welchem die zwei Bogen sich vereinigen, und indem
sie oben darauf liegen, nur senkrecht auf selbigen drücken, während ihre beiden andern Ende in die Pfeiler der Landfeste nach gewöhnlicher Art hineinlaufen und damit verbunden sind. Die Breite der Brücke ist mit Inbegriff der beiden Trottoirs 46 Fuss, und an Eisen wurde dazu nach Angabe eines Baudirigenten, der gegenwärtig war, 350 Tonnen oder 7000 Centner verbraucht. In Paris hätte nicht lange vorher eine ähnliche Brücke über die Seine gebaut werden sollen; allein es scheint, der Baumeister berechnete die Last, die die Pfeiler auszuhalten hatten, nicht gehörig; denn als sie fertig war, so wurden sie schon durch die Schwere der Ketten umgerissen, und da der arme Tropf, der Baumeister, sich darüber aus der Welt förderte, so bleibt nun Alles liegen. Die französischen Journale waren übrigens bei diesem Vorfalle sehr still. Die Haltbarkeit der Brücke zu Hamersmith wurde durch acht darauf gestellte und nachher noch im Trab dicht hintereinander darüber geführte
Wägen, jeder mit 60 Centnern beladen, probirt.

Da mein Zuhauseweg mich gerade bei Haymarket vorbeiführte, und es Theaterzeit (7 Uhr Abends) war, so ging ich hinein. Man muss in der That sagen, obschon der Eintritt bedeutend theurer ist als in Deutschland oder Frankreich, dass man für sein Geld auch etwas bekommt, ja nur fast zu viel. Denn nicht nur wurden drei Stücke gegeben, zwei Operetten und ein Lustspiel, sondern noch Zwischenbelustigungen (Sundry Entertainments), worunter hauptsächlich der Tanz und Gesang der recht hübschen und in der Theaterwelt vielseitig besprochenen Madame Vestris zu rechnen war, die als Fliegenwedel-Verkäuferin aus dem Odenwald, und in dortiger Tracht, mit ihrem bedeutungsvollen und doppelsinnigen «buy a broom» interessirte und belustigte.

Weil die Engländer in Allem einen grossen Werth auf die Zeit legen, und ihnen die Exsertionen des Orchesters, die auch
überhaupt mit denen auf unsern guten deutschen Bühnen, wie es mir wenigstens vorkam, gewiss nicht verglichen werden können, als ganz untergeordnet erscheinen, so fiel der Vorhang sowohl während dem Uebergang von einem Act zum andern, so wie auch von einem Stück zum andern, so zu sagen nur um wieder aufgezogen zu werden. Bei Allem diesem fast ununterbrochenen Spielen war es doch schon über Ein Uhr des Morgens, bis Alles endete, und ich hatte nun das Vergnügen, über zwei engl. Meilen weit zu Hause zu spazieren.

Uebrigens hatte mich auch jetzt wieder, wie früher, das so natürliche und ungezwungene Spiel der Acteurs erfreut, und ihre meistens natürliche oder nur äusserst wenig tingirte Gesichtsfarbe, welches Alles mit der Affectation und Ultra-Declamation der französischen Schauspieler und ihrer, man möchte sagen handhoch aufgetragenen Schminke sehr contrastirt. Von dem Costume will ich nichts erwähnen, denn man kann wohl denken, dass
in dem goldreichen England Papier und Flitter verbannt ist.

In dieser etwas mondhellen, aber doch kalten und neblichten Octobernacht traf ich verschiedene einzelne Personen, namentlich aber im Pater-noster-Row eine Frau mit vier Kindern vor einer Hausthüre auf dem Strassenpflaster liegend, wo sie die ganze Nacht zubrachten, an. So etwas erscheint bei uns fast unglaublich; wenn aber der zuverlässige Colqhuon, der London und seine Grösse und sein Elend wohl besser als fast Niemand kannte, irgendwo sagt, dass täglich daselbst circa 30,000 Menschen aufstehen, die nicht wissen, wo sie Abends ihr Haupt hinlegen wollen, so wird das, was ich so eben angeführt, nicht mehr auffallen. Noch muss ich der tragikomischen Geschichte von dem jungen Grimaldi erwähnen, die das Tagesgespräch von London ausmachte, und weil er als Clown oder Hanswurst das Publicum auf der Bühne sehr belustigt, auch heute Abend seiner häufig erwähnt wurde; nebst dem dass
es zugleich als Beitrag zur Sittengeschichte Londons gelten mag, so führe ich sie an. Er hatte eine Liebschaft mit einem Theater-Frauenzimmer, die aber nicht Agnes hiess. Er wurde ihrer überdrüssig und verabschiedete sie. Sie, in Wuth und Verzweiflung, nimmt auf der Stelle Gift. Die Symptome seiner Wirkung zeigen sich, sie sagt was sie gethan. Aerztliche Hülfe wird herbeigerufen, sie liegt aber hoffnungslos darnieder. Grimaldi erfährt es, geht hin sie zu sehen, und auch in Desperation, und um den Eindruck zu verwischen, den die Situation seiner ehemaligen Donna auf ihn gemacht, säuft er hintereinander zwei Bouteillen Branntwein. Er erreichte seinen Zweck vollkommen, denn er ward gleich darauf zum Narren. »It turn’d about bis brains» es kehrte ihm das Gehirn um, war der Ausdruck der darüber sogleich berichtenden Zeitungen. So sollten beide enden; indessen waren die Bemühungen, die man für beide anwendete, nicht fruchtlos, denn
allgemein wird nun versichert, sie sey wieder ausser Gefahr, und er bei Besinnung.

div.head: London Steelworks und ein sogenannter Tabakdispenser, 12. Oktober 1827
div.p:
Diesen Morgen ging ich nach London Steel-work, einer Gussstahl-Manufactur und Eisenfrisch-Schmiede, die den Herren Thomson und Johnson gehört, und oben an dem linken Themseufer, nicht weit von Vauxhall Bridge, liegt, um Gussstahl, den ich in Herrn Martineau’s Giesshaus aus russischem Eisen in directer Schmelzung erzeugt hatte, daselbst verstrecken zu lassen, da nebst dem Walzwerk diese Herren auch noch einen Aufwerfer, der mit daran gegossenem Stiel und Hülse oder vielmehr Warzen, 3 Tonnen oder 60 Centner wiegt, und zwei Streckhämmer, Alles durch eine und dieselbige Dampfmaschine getrieben, besitzen. Nebst diesen schon benannten Fabricaten verfertigen sie auch noch durch Zusammenschweissen von sogenanntem German Steel (eisenhaftem geringem Cement-Stahl) das Materiale für Kutschen- und Chaisefedern.
Auch hier wird zu diesem der neue, herrlich ausgesonnene Schweiss- und Glühherd angewendet, und sie machen Tropfhitzen von 12 bis 16 Zoll Länge. Es ist ganz gewiss, dass die Engländer in aller Art von Pyrotechnik, die sich auf Sieden, Glühen (und zwar unter den verschiedensten, und was höchst wichtig ist, genau in ihrer Gewalt habenden Hitzegraden), Brennen (Töpfergeschirr etc.) und Schmelzen bezieht, unsere Meister sind. Man findet aber auch so viele Vortheile und Handgriffe angewendet, die in der Physik und Chemie, welches ohnediess bald nur als eine einzige Wissenschaft betrachtet werden kann, ihre Grundlage haben, dass man den Beobachtungsgeist und das Nachdenken dieser Leute sehr bewundern muss; denn eben diese Vortheile, welches nachzuweisen ist, wurden meistens nur von gemeinen Arbeitern erfunden, denen die theoretischen Kenntnisse in obigen Wissenschaften, besonders in irgend einem Zusammenhange und Ver
bindung, ganz fremd waren. Warum dieser Verbesserungstrieb auf dem festen Lande, und besonders in Deutschland sich nirgends so zeigt, sondern die Meisten lieber bei dem Schlendrian, so wie sie ihn gelernt haben, bleiben, mag zum Theil in der Wandersucht (die von dem verständigen und zweckmässigen Reisen sehr zu unterscheiden ist) ihren Grund haben, und dann darin, dass einerseits der Meister, der eben auch nicht von viel Besserem weiss, statt sich, besonders bei einer wichtigen oder neuen Arbeit zu berathen, nur sein Meisterrecht und Infallibilität will geltend machen, und andererseits der Bruder Hamburger und Bruder Berliner seine Gloriole durch Einreden von seinem vielleicht jüngeren, aber dennoch erfahreneren Principal sich auch nicht will verkümmern lassen. Was ich übrigens hier gesagt, ist nicht aus der Luft gegriffen, sondern beruht auf eigener Erfahrung.

Während mein Stahl verstreckt wurde, kam einer der Arbeiter, der meinen Sohn
schon kannte, zu mir und wollte mich, unter Versicherung, dass er alle und jede Einrichtung dieses Werkes kenne, bereden, ihn mit auf das feste Land zu nehmen. Manchem wäre vielleicht ein solcher Antrag sehr willkommen gewesen, aber nicht nur hätte ich keine Arbeiter aus einer Fabrik debouchiren wollen, wo die Eigenthümer mir Gefälligkeit und Zutrauen erwiesen, sondern man muss sich bei uns überhaupt in Acht nehmen, einen sogenannten Engländer, was wir so ziemlich als synonym mit non plus ultra betrachten, anzustellen; denn sie kosten verdammt viel Geld, sind gar öfters Trunkenbolde, da die ordentlichen und zugleich geschickten immer in England ihr gutes Auskommen finden, und sie selten, wenn sie auch wirklich das Ganze der Fabrication, was übrigens sehr rar ist, und nur von einem guten sogenannten Foreman oder Werkführer erwartet werden kann, kennen, der Erwartung entsprechen, weil sie mit anderm Materiale und
mit andern Menschen, als wie in ihrem Lande sind, zu thun haben.

Bei unserm Zuhausegehen erblickten wir das Dampfboot, welches täglich (und wie ich glaube, mehrere Male) den Weg zwischen Richmond und London macht. Es ist das kleinste und niedlichste was ich noch je gesehen, und legt den Weg, 15 Meilen, wie man mir gesagt, in kaum 5/4 Stunden zurück. Dieses ist schon eine sehr grosse Geschwindigkeit, kommt aber der des Dampfboots Caroline noch bei Weitem nicht bei, welches regulair zwischen London und Margate geht, und diese Entfernung von 100 englischen Meilen in sechs, und wenn Wind und Fluth sich günstig erzeigt, sogar in fünf Stunden zurücklegen soll. Um nach Southwark zu kommen, ging ich über Waterloo Bridge. Diese Brücke ist sehr massiv, aber nach meinem Geschmack zu urtheilen, nicht geschmackvoll. Einen solchen reinen und erhabenen Styl, wie in Paris an der Börse, in Mün
chen an dem Theater und der Glyptothek, und den in Wien, Berlin und mehreren andern Residenzen Deutschlands an so häufigen neuern Bauwerken, habe ich in England, so viel mir zu Gesicht gekommen, an keinem öffentlichen Gebäude angetroffen; die Mechanik hingegen hat bei dieser Brücke auch ihr Scherflein müssen beitragen. Da die Fussgänger nämlich einen Zoll zu bezahlen und durch ein Drehkreuz (Trille) durchzugehen haben, der Bezieher des Zolls aber nur ein Angestellter ist, so ist mit selbigem ein Indicator im innern Zimmer verbunden, welcher auf Tage, Wochen und Monate anzeigt, wie viele Personen hin- oder her passirt sind. Auch in anderer, wirklich belustigender Beziehung ist diese nachrechnende oder in diesem Fall preisbestimmende Mechanik zum grossen Leidwesen der Tabakraucher, die etwa gern im Wirthshaus eine Pfeife gratis stopfen möchten, angebracht. In England nämlich wird meistens nur von Ausländern und dann von
Militärpersonen, Seefahrenden, und den Eingebornen aus den untern Klassen geraucht. In den bessern Caffeehäusern geschieht es auch nicht, wohl aber in den geringern, wo dann für diesen Behuf eigene Smoking rooms oder Rauchzimmer vorhanden sind. Man pflegt aber nicht so Pfeife und Tabak mit sich zu führen, wie bei uns zu Lande. Die Pfeife (weisse irdene) bekommt man bei dem Wirth, der Tabak aber steht auf dem Tische in einer verschlossenen Büchse von Weissblech. Für den Wirth wäre es viel zu weitläufig und unsicher, den Betrag für jede Pfeife, die man stopft, und der einen Penny oder drei Kreuzer nach unserm Gelde ausmacht, von dem Consumenten zu beziehen. Die Tabakbüchse hat demnach eine besondere Abtheilung mit einem Loch, wie bei einer Armenbüchse, in welches gerade ein Penny hineingeht. Inwendig nun, dem Loch gegenüber, ist der Arm eines Hebels, dessen anderes Ende mit dem Riegel, welcher den
Deckel der Tabaksbüchse schliesst, in Verbindung steht, und seine Länge so calculirt, dass nur das Gewicht von einem Penny und kein geringeres ihn zu öffnen vermag. Will man nun seine Pfeife stopfen, so wirft man einen Penny hinein, der Deckel springt auf, und der Raucher hat, was er verlangt. Glaubt etwa einer mit einem halben Penny durchzukommen, so wird der Betrug auf der Stelle bestraft, die Büchse, weil das Gewicht für den Hebel zu leicht ist, bleibt unerbittlich geschlossen, und er muss noch einen ganzen Penny dazuthun, weil ein zweiter halber nicht hinreicht, die Büchse zu öffnen, da der erste halbe nicht auf dem Hebel liegen bleibt.

div.head: Rückreise über Paris, 13.–21. Oktober 1827
div.p:
Den Hauptgegenstand meiner Geschäfte heute beendigt, hatte ich keine Veranlassung mehr in London zu bleiben, und nahm, um Zeit zu gewinnen, wieder in der Abends von London nach Dover abgehenden Kutsche einen Platz. Das Dampfboot the Sovereign brachte mich am 14ten
unter Sturm und Ungewitter nach Calais, und der dort abgehende Courier am 15ten Mittags nach Amiens und am 16ten Morgens um 4 Uhr nach Paris.

Um einige Geschäfte zu besorgen, blieb ich den 16ten und 17ten daselbst, und hatte das Vergnügen in der Bekanntschaft mit dem Herrn Delessert, Banquier von Paris, einem der distinguirtesten Schweizer daselbst, an den ich übrigens gar nicht empfohlen war, sondern nur einen mündlichen Auftrag von Herrn Perkins auszurichten hatte, in Hinsicht der Urbanität den Gegensatz mit der Schmutzigkeit eines Geldhändlers in London, der übrigens kein Engländer istFischer meint Nathan Mayer Rothschild, den er am 24. und 27. September 1827 traf., und an den ich von einem seiner Freunde einige Zeilen zu übergeben im Fall war, in dem grellsten Lichte zu erblicken. Am 17ten Abends um 6 Uhr ging ich von Paris weg, war am 18ten Mittags in Chalons sur Marne, am 19ten Abends in Strassburg, am 20sten über Basel gehend bis Nachts um 9 Uhr, wo ich unterweges einem grossen
Unglück, durch die Nachlässigkeit des Kutschers verursacht, sehr wunderbar entging, in Stein bei Säkingen, und am 21sten Nachmittags Gottlob glücklich und wohl zu Hause.

Schwerlich werde ich mehr dieses Land, das ich seit so Kurzem verlassen, und worin ich so Manches gesehen und mich über so Manches belehrt, wieder besuchen; aber zwei Sachen, als Resultate meiner wiederholten Beobachtungen, werden auch entfernt von demselbigen meinem Geiste beständig vorschweben.

Erstlich aus welchen Ursachen und durch welche Mittel nicht die Industrie, sondern der Geist und Sinn für Industrie und ihre Art und Weise, sich dort so ausgebildet hat (politische und pecuniäre Macht allein erzwingen dieses nicht; Spanien hatte nie eine, wenn schon zu einer Zeit in den Ländern seiner Beherrscher die Sonne nie unterging), und wie nun aber, weil nichts Menschliches unveränderlich bleibt, der Culmina
tions-Punkt in dieser Hinsicht in England daselbst schon eingetreten zu sein scheint; seitdem, da die Vorsehung, als Erzieherin des Menschengeschlechts, es so gewollt hat, als Folge des Continental-Systems, das Festland zur Erkenntniss seiner Kräfte gekommen ist, und, wo immer sie gepflegt und genährt werden, mit täglich grösserem Erfolg dasjenige aus eigenem Schoose hervorgerufen wird, was die Nothwendigkeit des Lebens erheischt, und was dasselbige ziert und erfreut.
